SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graham)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: MARGARET T. MC MANUS
Present Address: MADISON, SASK.
Pioneer Address: RATHMULLEN, NORMAC
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? about 12 or 15

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 3 or 4

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? quite often but not at times

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sunday sometimes also on weekdays

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? we didn't both ways

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? mostly afternoon I stayed for supper

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? sometimes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Welcome to what we have

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? tea or coffee

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? on special occasions we all went

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? yes

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

To help put shingles on roofs? Help for the well if something went wrong with the pipes

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. Yes, there was not room enough

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Lots of parties dancas, card games held in the school. After it was built in 1910

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, FRIENDS, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? about 12 or 15

2. How many of these were bachelor's homes? 3 or 4

3. How often did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Usually after lunch or over afternoon tea.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? We did, both ways.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Sometimes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "make a potlatch" used or was some other expression common?) Welcome to what we have.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Tea or coffee

6. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? On special occasions we all went

7. In the earliest years that you were here were there many parties, what drives or dances in homes? Describe. Yes, very few, very few.

Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates. Lots of parties, bull-

clans, and games held in the school. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, twice a month, etc.? No

If you have not described these on the school, (signature), please do so.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school itself? How much outside?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village of Holden

To what extent did it take the place of house or the school house as a place for social activities? If so, describe. (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and came to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

A community hall was built in Holden, and our school house for gatherings.
